H0.text: Ocean currents move the greatest amount of heat away from the equator on Earth, where solar radiation provides more heat near the equator than near the poles.

H1.text: Aquatic plants move the greatest amount of heat away from the equator.

H2.text: Surface winds are the greatest mechanism by which heat is moved away from the equator on Earth, where solar radiation provides more heat near the equator than near the poles.

H3.text: Tectonic plates move the greatest amount of heat away from the equator, where solar radiation provides more heat than near the poles on Earth.

A4.text: The work produced by that engine causes the motion of the masses of air, and in that process it redistributes the energy absorbed by Earth's surface near the tropics to the latitudes nearer the poles, and thence to space.

A5.text: The sheer volume of energy that the Hadley cell transports, and the depth of the heat sink contained within the polar cell, ensures that transient weather phenomena not only have negligible effect on the systems as a whole, but—except under unusual circumstances—they do not form.

A6.text: These western ocean currents transport warm, sub-tropical water polewards toward the polar regions.

A7.text: The westerlies play an important role in carrying the warm, equatorial waters and winds to the western coasts of continents, especially in the southern hemisphere because of its vast oceanic expanse.

A8.text: The Gulf Stream carries warm water northeast across the Atlantic, making Western Europe and especially Northern Europe warmer and milder than it otherwise would be.

A9.text: It transports water at a rate of 30 million cubic metres per second (30 sverdrups) through the Florida Straits.
